sandra.examples.oneshot.voicelaunch
Class VoiceLaunch

java.lang.Object
  android.content.Context
      android.content.ContextWrapper
          android.view.ContextThemeWrapper
              android.app.Activity
                  sandra.libs.asr.asrlib.ASR
                      sandra.examples.oneshot.voicelaunch.VoiceLaunch
All Implemented Interfaces:
android.content.ComponentCallbacks, android.content.ComponentCallbacks2, android.speech.RecognitionListener, android.view.KeyEvent.Callback, android.view.LayoutInflater.Factory, android.view.LayoutInflater.Factory2, android.view.View.OnCreateContextMenuListener, android.view.Window.Callback
public class VoiceLaunch
extends ASR

VoiceLaunch: it launches the app mentioned by the user It uses the ASRLib and TTSLib libraries for speech recognition, as well a library from Apache commons: http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-codec/index.html

Version:
4.1, 08/07/13
Author:
Zoraida Callejas, Michael McTear

private void showMatchingNames(java.util.ArrayList<VoiceLaunch.MyApp> sortedApps)
Shows the matching apps and their similarity values on the GUI

Parameters:
sortedApps - It is a tree map in which the last element is the most similar, and the first the least

setListView

Parameters:
nBestView - list of matches

getSimilarAppsSorted

private java.util.ArrayList<VoiceLaunch.MyApp> getSimilarAppsSorted(java.lang.String recogizedName)
Obtains a collection with information about the apps which name is similar to what was recognized from the user. The collection is sorted from most to least similar.

Parameters:
recognizedName - Name of the app recognized from the user input
Returns:
A collection of instances of MyApp. MyApp is an auxiliary class that we have created (see at the bottom of this file), to store information about the apps retreived, concretely: name, package name and similarity to recognized name. If no apps are found, it returns an empty list.

normalize

private java.lang.String normalize(java.lang.String text)
Normalizes a text

Parameters:
text -
Returns:
the input text without spaces and in lower case

compareOrthographic

private double compareOrthographic(java.lang.String a,
                                   java.lang.String b)
Compares the names using the Levenshtein distance, which is the minimal number of characters you have to replace, insert or delete to transform string a into string b. We have used a computation of this distance provided by Wikipedia.

Returns:
similarity from 0 (minimum) to 1 (maximum)

comparePhonetic

private double comparePhonetic(java.lang.String recognizedApp,
                               java.lang.String nameApp)
Compares the names using their phonetic similarity, using the soundex algorithm. We have used an implementation of this algorithm provided by Apache. Attention: it only works for English

startListeningForApps

private void startListeningForApps()
Listens for names of apps. Depending of the recognition results, the methods processError, processReadyForSpeech or processResults will be invoked. Speech recognition is carried out in US English because it is the only language for which phonetic similarity works

processAsrResults

public void processAsrResults(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> nBestList,
                              float[] nBestConfidences)
When recognition is successful, it obtains the best recognition result (supposedly the name of an app), and sorts all apps installed on the device according to the similarity of their names to the one recognized (considering only the ones similar above a threshold). Then, it launches the app with highest similarity. If the similarities are all bellow the defined threshold, no app is launched and the user gets a feedback message in a Toast

Specified by:
processAsrResults in class ASR
Parameters:
nBestList - List of the N recognition results
nBestConfidences - List of the N corresponding confidences

launchApp

private void launchApp(VoiceLaunch.MyApp app)
Launches the app indicated.

Parameters:
app - see the MyApp class defined at the end of this file
